content.question: A block of mass <math alttext="1 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> slides on a frictionless, horizontal surface with a velocity of <math alttext="3.0 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m/</mtext><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to the right, as shown above, and collides with a block of mass <math alttext="2 kilograms" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is at rest. As a result of the collision, the <math alttext="1 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> block comes to rest. Which of the following correctly states whether the collision is elastic or inelastic and provides a valid justification?

choices.label: Elastic, because the total momentum before the collision equals the total momentum after.
Elastic, because some of the initial kinetic energy is converted to other forms of energy but the total energy is conserved.
Inelastic, because the total momentum before the collision does not equal the total momentum after.
Inelastic, because some of the initial kinetic energy is converted into nonmechanical energy.

content.answer: Inelastic, because some of the initial kinetic energy is converted into nonmechanical energy.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
